metadata.titleEn: Dataset of seasonal maximum freezing depth with 1 km resolution in 2050s and 2090s over the Third Pole
metadata.description: The maximum freezing depth is an important index of seasonally frozen ground. Observation and simulation show that the maximum freezing depth is decreasing. In this paper, the data set of maximum freezing depth for 2050s (2041-2060) and 2090s (2081-2100) in the Third Pole under the scenarios of SSP126, SSP245, SSP370 and SSP585 is released, with a spatial resolution of 1 km. The data set is obtained by using the average of 200 set simulations of the support vector regression model in the baseline period (2001-2010). The validation results show that the support vector regression model has good accuracy and stability. Based on this data set, it is found that under four climate scenarios, the maximum freezing depth in the Third Polar from 2001 to 2100 will be significantly reduced by 10.41 cm (11.69%), 24.00 cm (26.95%), 37.71 cm (42.34%) and 47.71 cm (53.57%), respectively. This data set provides data support for the study of seasonally frozen ground in the Third Pole, Asian mountains and other regions.
metadata.instructions: There are 8 files in the folder in Geotiff format, which are the maximum freezing depths for 2050s (2041-2060) and 2090s (2081-2100) under SSP126, SSP245, SSP370 and SSP585 scenarios, for example, "2050s_SSP126.tif" represents the maximum freezing depths for 2050s under SSP126 scenarios.

background: The maximum soil freezing depth (MSFD) is an important indicator of the thermal state of seasonally frozen ground, and its variation plays a significant role in the hydrological processes, energy transformation, biochemical processes and engineering construction of cold regions. Recent studies have shown that the MSFD has continued to decrease over the past few decades. The MSFD on the QTP declined by an average of 4.9 cm per decade from 1960 to 2014. The mapping methods of the MSFD include empirical models, physical models and statistical/machine learning models. The in situ observed data play an important role in the calibration and validation of the MSFD model because of its high accuracy. Statistical/machine learning models are an alternative approach for simulating the MSFD. Remote sensing provides important technical means and environmental variables for observing the thermal state of frozen ground. Many previous studies have shown that it is feasible to estimate the freezing/thawing state of soil using microwave remote sensing, because it is very sensitive to the near surface dielectric properties and has the ability to penetrate clouds.
research objective: Therefore, with the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau (QTP) as a study area, the objectives of this study were (1) to compare the effects of different statistical/machine learning models on the simulation of the MSFD; (2) to assess the impact of remote sensing observations on the simulation of the MSFD; and (3) to evaluate the trainability of statistical/machine learning models built during the baseline period (2001–2010) to simulate the MSFD for historical periods (1981–1990 and 1991–2010).
challenges: However, in situ observations are limited and costly to obtain. The estimated results using the Stefan solution will have large errors if the basic assumption (i.e., a linear temperature gradient and constant heat conductivity in the soil and a steady upper boundary condition) are not met. Nevertheless, the simulation accuracy and computational efficiency of the physical models are still poor. The physical processes and parametric schemes for physical models need further enhancement and improvement.
methods: In this study, we first classified (variables were classified into remote sensing variable sets and climate variable sets) and optimized (variables were ranked by importance) these predictors. Then, four statistical/machine learning models with different predictors were compared based on the results of cross-validation, and an optimal model combination (i.e., machine learning model with predictors that performed better than others) was used to simulate the MSFD on the QTP. Finally, the transferability of the model for the baseline period was tested. Tenfold cross-validation was used to evaluate the predictive performance of each machine/statistical model. A total of 184 ground-measured SFD sample points were collected from 2001 to 2010 on the QTP. For each model, 165 sample points were used for model training, and the remaining 19 sample points were used for model validation. To reduce the uncertainty of the model, each model was run 200 times, and the arithmetic average was used as the final simulation accuracy. The root mean square error (RMSE), coefficient of determination (R 2) and bias (mean difference) were used to evaluate the performance of the model.
dataset: In this study, daily soil freezing depth measurement data from 184 meteorological stations on the QTP were collected from 1981 to 2010. Due to the lack of data from some sites, the numbers of sites available in 1981–1990, 1991–2000, and 2001–2010 were 84, 89, and 184, respectively. The altitude of these sites was 846–4800 m, and the MSFD was 3.7–276.6 cm. The multiyear average FDD and TDD were generated by calculating the 1 km resolution MODIS products (MOD11A1 and MYD11A 1 v5) four times a day.
findings: The results show that support vector regression (SVR) performs better than random forest (RF), k-nearest neighbor (KNN) and the ensemble mean of the three models. Compared with the climate predictors, the remote sensing predictors are helpful for improving the simulation accuracy of the MSFD at both decadal and annual scales (at the annual and decadal scales, the root mean square error (RMSE) is reduced by 2.84 and 1.99 cm, respectively). The SVR model with climate predictor calibration using the in situ MSFD at the baseline period (2001–2010) can be used to simulate the MSFD over historical periods (1981–1990 and 1991–2000). This result indicates the good transferability of the well-trained machine learning model and its availability to simulate the MSFD of the past and the future when remote sensing predictors are not available.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to measure the maximum soil freezing depth (MSFD) in high-altitude regions?
Example.Answer: In high-altitude regions like the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau, daily soil freezing depth measurement data were collected from meteorological stations. A total of 184 ground-measured sample points were collected from 2001 to 2010.

Example.Question: What is an example of a machine learning model used to simulate the maximum soil freezing depth, and how is its performance evaluated?

Example.Question: Can you give an example of how remote sensing data is integrated with machine learning models to improve the simulation of the maximum soil freezing depth?
Example.Answer: Remote sensing predictors, as compared to climate predictors, are shown to improve the simulation accuracy of the MSFD. This integration reduces the RMSE by 2.84 cm at the annual scale and 1.99 cm at the decadal scale when support vector regression (SVR) is used.

Definition.Question: How do 'statistical/machine learning models' contribute to the simulation of maximum soil freezing depth?
Definition.Answer: Statistical/machine learning models are an alternative approach for simulating the maximum soil freezing depth (MSFD). They allow for the integration of various predictors, including remote sensing and climate variables, and have demonstrated good performance in terms of simulation accuracy and the ability to simulate MSFD over historical periods.

Definition.Question: What role do 'remote sensing observations' play in the assessment of maximum soil freezing depth?
Definition.Answer: Remote sensing provides important technical means and environmental variables for observing the thermal state of frozen ground. It is feasible to estimate the freezing/thawing state of soil using microwave remote sensing because it is sensitive to near-surface dielectric properties and can penetrate clouds, thus improving the simulation accuracy of the maximum soil freezing depth.

Comparison.Question: How does the use of remote sensing variables compare to climate variables in terms of improving the simulation accuracy of the maximum soil freezing depth (MSFD)?
Comparison.Answer: Remote sensing predictors are shown to improve the simulation accuracy of the MSFD at both decadal and annual scales compared to climate predictors. The root mean square error (RMSE) is reduced by 2.84 cm annually and 1.99 cm decadal scale when remote sensing predictors are used.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in data collection challenges between in situ observations and remote sensing techniques for studying MSFD?
Comparison.Answer: In situ observations are limited and costly to obtain, posing significant challenges. In contrast, remote sensing techniques provide important technical means and variables for observing the thermal state of frozen ground, and are feasible for estimating the freezing/thawing state of soil, due to their sensitivity to near-surface dielectric properties and ability to penetrate clouds.

Comparison.Question: How does the performance of support vector regression (SVR) compare to other machine learning models like random forest (RF) and k-nearest neighbor (KNN) for simulating MSFD?
Comparison.Answer: Support vector regression (SVR) performs better than random forest (RF), k-nearest neighbor (KNN), and the ensemble mean of these models for simulating MSFD, indicating its superiority in predictive performance.

Interpretation.Question: What insights can be drawn about the impact of remote sensing observations on simulating maximum soil freezing depth, and how do these insights inform the choice of predictors in data collection?
Interpretation.Answer: Remote sensing observations enhance the accuracy of simulating maximum soil freezing depth (MSFD) by providing valuable environmental variables that are sensitive to the thermal state of frozen ground. These insights suggest that including remote sensing predictors alongside climate predictors can improve the model performance, as evidenced by a reduction in root mean square error. This informs data collection methods by highlighting the importance of integrating remote sensing data into the model predictors.

Interpretation.Question: How do the challenges faced in in situ data collection for maximum soil freezing depth influence the design of machine learning models for predictive simulations?
Interpretation.Answer: In situ data collection for maximum soil freezing depth is limited and costly, which challenges the calibration and validation of models. This limitation influences the design of machine learning models by necessitating the use of alternative data sources, such as remote sensing, and robust validation techniques like cross-validation. It also emphasizes the importance of model transferability and the ability to generalize well to different temporal periods and conditions.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the reduced accuracy and computational efficiency in physical models when simulating the maximum soil freezing depth?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The simulation accuracy and computational efficiency of physical models are poor due to the limited in situ observations and the large errors that arise if the basic assumption of a linear temperature gradient, constant heat conductivity in the soil, and a steady upper boundary condition are not met. Additionally, the physical processes and parametric schemes for these models need further enhancement and improvement.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why are remote sensing predictors considered beneficial for improving the simulation accuracy of maximum soil freezing depth?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Remote sensing predictors are beneficial because they provide important technical means and environmental variables for observing the thermal state of frozen ground. They are particularly sensitive to the near-surface dielectric properties and have the ability to penetrate clouds, which helps in estimating the freezing/thawing state of soil more accurately.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the reasons behind the choice of support vector regression as the optimal model for simulating maximum soil freezing depth?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Support vector regression is chosen as the optimal model because it performs better than random forest, k-nearest neighbor, and the ensemble mean of these models. It shows good transferability and availability to simulate the MSFD of the past and the future when remote sensing predictors are not available, indicating its robustness and reliability in different scenarios.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences on the accuracy of maximum soil freezing depth (MSFD) simulations when using remote sensing data as a predictor compared to relying solely on in situ observations?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The use of remote sensing data as a predictor can improve the simulation accuracy of MSFD over relying solely on in situ observations. Remote sensing predictors reduce the root mean square error (RMSE) by 2.84 cm on an annual scale and 1.99 cm on a decadal scale, indicating enhanced accuracy.

Causal Consequence.Question: What might be the impact on the simulation of maximum soil freezing depth (MSFD) when employing machine learning models developed during a baseline period, in comparison to other historical periods?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Employing machine learning models developed during a baseline period (2001–2010) can effectively simulate MSFD for historical periods (1981–1990 and 1991–2000). This approach shows good transferability of the model, indicating that it can simulate past MSFD accurately when remote sensing predictors are not available.

Causal Consequence.Question: What could be the implications of using support vector regression over other machine learning models like random forest or k-nearest neighbor in predicting maximum soil freezing depth (MSFD)?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using support vector regression over other machine learning models such as random forest or k-nearest neighbor results in better performance in predicting MSFD. It consistently shows improved simulation accuracy, making it a preferable choice among the tested models for this application.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is integrating remote sensing data considered crucial in the simulation of the maximum soil freezing depth?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Integrating remote sensing data is crucial because it provides important environmental variables that are highly sensitive to the thermal state of frozen ground. The use of remote sensing data helps improve the simulation accuracy of the maximum soil freezing depth (MSFD), especially when traditional methods face challenges due to limited in situ observations and assumptions that may not hold true in some cases.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the objectives behind using a baseline period model to simulate historical maximum soil freezing depths?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The objectives are to assess the transferability and reliability of statistical/machine learning models developed during a baseline period (2001–2010) for simulating historical maximum soil freezing depths (MSFD) in earlier periods. This approach aims to validate the model's ability to accurately predict past MSFD when remote sensing predictors are not available, thereby demonstrating the model's robustness and usefulness for both historical and future predictions.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are involved in selecting and optimizing predictors for machine learning models aimed at simulating maximum soil freezing depth (MSFD) in cold regions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: In the field, variables are first classified into remote sensing variable sets and climate variable sets. These predictors are then ranked by importance, and four statistical/machine learning models with different predictors are compared using cross-validation. An optimal model combination is chosen, and its transferability is tested, specifically for the baseline period of 2001–2010. This involves evaluating the predictive performance using metrics like RMSE, R2, and bias.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How is remote sensing data integrated with in situ observations to improve the accuracy of simulating the maximum soil freezing depth?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Remote sensing data provides important environmental variables for observing the thermal state of frozen ground. The integration involves using remote sensing predictors in combination with in situ observed data, which is crucial for calibrating and validating the models. The integration enhances simulation accuracy by reducing RMSE at both decadal and annual scales compared to using only climate predictors.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What challenges are encountered in collecting in situ observations for maximum soil freezing depth, and how are these addressed in modeling approaches?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The challenges include limited and costly in situ observations, as well as potential large errors from the Stefan solution if assumptions are not met. To address these, the use of statistical/machine learning models is recommended, as they provide an alternative approach with better accuracy and efficiency. Additionally, data from 184 meteorological stations collected over several decades are used to train and validate models, ensuring robust simulation results.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements have enabled the use of remote sensing observations to improve the simulation accuracy of soil freezing depth in seasonally frozen grounds?
Enablement.Answer: Remote sensing provides important technical means and environmental variables for observing the thermal state of frozen ground, and microwave remote sensing is particularly effective because of its sensitivity to near-surface dielectric properties and its ability to penetrate clouds.

Enablement.Question: How does the classification and optimization of predictors enhance the performance of machine learning models in simulating maximum soil freezing depth?
Enablement.Answer: Classifying predictors into remote sensing and climate variable sets and optimizing them by ranking their importance allows for the comparison and selection of optimal model combinations, improving simulation accuracy.

Enablement.Question: What conditions or strategies are necessary for ensuring the transferability of machine learning models built during a baseline period to simulate historical and future maximum soil freezing depths?
Enablement.Answer: The use of statistical/machine learning models trained with in situ MSFD data during a baseline period (2001–2010) and validated through cross-validation techniques ensures their transferability to simulate MSFD over historical periods and potentially future scenarios.

Expectation.Question: Why might a dataset using support vector regression (SVR) provide better simulation accuracy for maximum soil freezing depth compared to other machine learning models?
Expectation.Answer: The results show that support vector regression (SVR) performs better than random forest (RF), k-nearest neighbor (KNN), and the ensemble mean of the three models. This suggests SVR is more effective in capturing the complex relationships within the data for simulating maximum soil freezing depth.

Expectation.Question: Why is it anticipated that a well-trained machine learning model can simulate past and future maximum soil freezing depths even when remote sensing predictors are unavailable?
Expectation.Answer: The well-trained machine learning model, specifically with support vector regression (SVR), demonstrates good transferability and can simulate maximum soil freezing depths for historical periods. This suggests that the model can be effectively used for future simulations when remote sensing predictors are not available.

Judgmental.Question: What are your thoughts on the effectiveness of using support vector regression (SVR) as a machine learning model for simulating maximum soil freezing depth in high-altitude regions?
Judgmental.Answer: Support vector regression (SVR) is noted to perform better than other models like random forest (RF) and k-nearest neighbor (KNN) in simulating maximum soil freezing depth. It shows good predictive performance, particularly when enhanced with climate predictors and remote sensing data, indicating its effectiveness for this application.

Judgmental.Question: How would you evaluate the challenges faced in utilizing in situ observations and remote sensing data for modeling maximum soil freezing depth?
Judgmental.Answer: In situ observations, while accurate, are limited and costly, presenting challenges in data collection. Remote sensing offers a valuable complement due to its ability to observe environmental variables and penetrate clouds, although integrating these data types requires careful calibration and validation to overcome assumptions in models like the Stefan solution.

It is feasible to estimate the freezing/thawing state of soil using microwave remote sensing because it is very sensitive to the near surface dielectric properties and has the ability to penetrate clouds.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore the challenges encountered in collecting in situ observations for soil freezing depth and propose alternative data collection methods.
Request/Directive.Answer: Challenges in collecting in situ observations for soil freezing depth include limited availability and high costs. An alternative data collection method could involve leveraging remote sensing techniques, as they provide important environmental variables and technical means for observing the thermal state of frozen ground, offering a more cost-effective and extensive data collection approach.
